description: From Middle English gift (also yift, yifte, ȝift, ȝeft), partly from Old English ġift (“giving, consideration, dowry, wedding”) and Old Norse gipt (“gift, present, wedding”); both from Proto-Germanic *giftiz (“gift”). Equivalent to give +‎ -th (etymologically yive + -th).

Cognate with West Frisian jefte (“gift”), Saterland Frisian Gift (“gift”),  German Low German Gift (“poison”), Dutch gift (“gift”) and its doublet gif (“poison”), German Gift (“poison”), Swedish gift (“gift, poison, venom”), Icelandic gift (“gift”). Doublet of yift.

entries.meaning: Something given to another voluntarily, without charge.

examples: She had a gift for playing the flute.

entries.meaning: The act, right, or power of giving or bestowing.
examples: The office is in the gift of the President.

verbs.description: gift (third-person singular simple present gifts, present participle gifting, simple past and past participle gifted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give as a gift or donation.
(transitive) To give away, to concede easily.
